verses.text: Now it happened, as Jesus was praying in a certain place, when He finished, one of His disciples said to Him, 'Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples.'
verses.comment: This sets the context for the Lord's Prayer. Prayer patterns from Jewish tradition are evident. Jesus is seen as the authoritative Teacher, showing His unique status.

verses.text: He said to them, 'When you pray, say: Father, hallowed be Your name. Your kingdom come.'
verses.comment: This prayer addresses God intimately as 'Father', and invokes His holiness and coming reign, emphasizing both the transcendence and immanence of God.

verses.text: Give us each day our daily bread.
verses.comment: 'Daily bread' echoes the manna in the wilderness. This requests God’s provision for physical needs, but can also be read as spiritual nourishment.

verses.text: And forgive us our sins, for we ourselves forgive everyone who is indebted to us. And lead us not into temptation.'
verses.comment: Direct link between God's forgiveness toward us and our forgiveness toward others. Temptation is seen as a danger from which only God can deliver.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'Suppose one of you has a friend and goes to him at midnight and says, Friend, lend me three loaves of bread,
verses.comment: This parable on prayer stresses persistence in asking God for our needs, indicating the openness and generosity of God.

verses.text: for a friend of mine has arrived on a journey, and I have nothing to set before him.'
verses.comment: Hospitality was a deep cultural obligation; the need arises from love of neighbor, mirroring the Christian call to charity.

verses.text: And he will answer from within, ‘Do not trouble me; the door is now shut, and my children are with me in bed. I cannot get up and give you anything.'
verses.comment: The reluctance in the parable contrasts with God, who is never reluctant to respond to His children.

verses.text: I tell you, even though he will not get up and give him anything because he is his friend, yet because of his shameless boldness he will rise and give him whatever he needs.
verses.comment: The phrase 'shameless boldness' refers to persistent, confident prayer—encouraging believers to boldly bring their petitions before God.

verses.text: So I tell you, ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.
verses.comment: Jesus promises that God responds to prayer, emphasizing the need for faith and perseverance.

verses.text: For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be opened.
verses.comment: Confirms the universality of the promise for all disciples, reinforcing trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: What father among you, if his son asks for a fish, will instead of a fish give him a snake?
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts human paternal love with the perfect generosity of the heavenly Father.

verses.text: Or if he asks for an egg, will he give him a scorpion?
verses.comment: A scorpion was a common desert danger—another image of God’s protection from harm.

verses.text: If you then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask Him!'
verses.comment: The greatest gift is the Holy Spirit, given in response to persistent prayer—a foreshadowing of the Spirit’s outpouring upon the Church.

verses.text: Now He was casting out a demon that was mute. When the demon had come out, the mute man spoke, and the crowds were amazed.
verses.comment: Jesus' power over demons demonstrates His divine authority. This act fulfills messianic prophecies regarding opening the mouths of the mute (Isa. 35:6).

verses.text: But some of them said, 'He casts out demons by Beelzebul, the prince of demons.'
verses.comment: Opponents accuse Jesus of operating with demonic power—an attempt to undermine His divine authority.

verses.text: Others, to test Him, kept seeking from Him a sign from heaven.
verses.comment: Demanding a sign reveals hardness of heart and unwillingness to believe what has already been revealed.

verses.text: But He, knowing their thoughts, said to them, 'Every kingdom divided against itself is laid waste, and a divided house falls.'
verses.comment: Jesus knows their thoughts—a mark of divine insight. Warning about division addresses the illogic of their accusation.

verses.text: And if Satan also is divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? For you say that I cast out demons by Beelzebul.
verses.comment: Logical refutation: Satan would not cast out his own demons. Jesus' authority transcends satanic power.

verses.text: And if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore, they will be your judges.
verses.comment: Jewish exorcists are acknowledged, but Jesus uses their own logic to show their bias.

verses.text: But if I cast out demons by the finger of God, then the kingdom of God has come upon you.
verses.comment: 'Finger of God' references God's direct action and the authority of Jesus (divine Messiah). Kingdom presence means God’s reign is active through Christ.

verses.text: When a strong man, fully armed, guards his own house, his possessions are safe.
verses.comment: The 'strong man' is a metaphor for Satan protecting his realm until one greater arrives.

verses.text: But when one stronger than he attacks him and overpowers him, he takes away his armor in which he trusted, and divides his spoil.
verses.comment: Jesus is the 'stronger one' who defeats the enemy, liberating those enslaved (fulfillment of Isaiah’s prophecy of deliverance).

verses.text: Whoever is not with Me is against Me, and whoever does not gather with Me scatters.
verses.comment: No neutrality with Christ; He demands commitment. Gathering hints at the unity and mission of the chosen people.

verses.text: When an unclean spirit goes out of a person, it passes through waterless places, seeking rest. And not finding any, it says, 'I will return to my house from which I came.'
verses.comment: Demons seek rest outside their former host; imagery reflects the Jewish concept of the wilderness as a place of evil.

verses.text: And when it comes, it finds the house swept and put in order.
verses.comment: Mere cleansing is not enough—the Spirit of God must dwell in a person to prevent relapse into evil.

verses.text: Then it goes and brings along seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and dwell there. And the last state of that person is worse than the first.'
verses.comment: Warning against spiritual complacency and the necessity of true conversion and indwelling of God’s presence.

verses.text: As He said these things, a woman in the crowd raised her voice and said to Him, 'Blessed is the womb that bore You, and the breasts at which You nursed!'
verses.comment: Reference to the unique blessing of Jesus’ mother. The physical link to Christ is honored, but will be further clarified in the response.

verses.text: But He said, 'Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and keep it!'
verses.comment: True blessedness is found in obeying God—not merely in physical connection. This includes the spiritual motherhood and kinship of believers with Christ.

verses.text: When the crowds were increasing, He began to say, 'This generation is an evil generation. It seeks a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah.'
verses.comment: Sign of Jonah alludes to Jesus' death and resurrection after three days—the ultimate sign of His authority.

verses.text: For as Jonah became a sign to the people of Nineveh, so will the Son of Man be to this generation.
verses.comment: 'Son of Man'—a title for the Messiah—will likewise serve as the ultimate sign, fulfilling the typology established in Jonah.

verses.text: The Queen of the South will rise up at the judgment with the men of this generation and condemn them, for she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon. And look, something greater than Solomon is here.
verses.comment: Gentile openness to God’s revelation is contrasted with Israel’s hardness. Jesus is declared greater than Solomon—a statement of His divinity and wisdom.

verses.text: The men of Nineveh will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for they repented at the preaching of Jonah, and look, something greater than Jonah is here.
verses.comment: Jesus is the true prophet. The people of Nineveh, once evil, repented—serving as a warning to those who do not heed Christ’s call.

verses.text: 'No one lights a lamp and puts it in a cellar or under a basket, but on a stand, so that those who enter may see the light.'
verses.comment: The lamp is an image of revelation and discipleship—faith and truth are to be shared openly.

verses.text: 'Your eye is the lamp of your body. When your eye is healthy, your whole body also is full of light, but when it is bad, your body is full of darkness.'
verses.comment: The 'eye' signifies the heart’s spiritual vision. Spiritual clarity leads to holiness, while spiritual blindness leads to sin.

verses.text: 'Therefore take care lest the light in you be darkness.'
verses.comment: Warning against self-deception: to ensure that one’s supposed 'light' is true light from God.

verses.text: 'If then your whole body is full of light, having no part dark, it will be completely bright, as when a lamp with its rays gives you light.'
verses.comment: The call is to spiritual integrity and complete transformation—the goal of the Christian life.

verses.text: While Jesus was speaking, a Pharisee asked Him to dine with him, so He went in and reclined at table.
verses.comment: Dining together signified potential openness or challenge. Meals are recurring moments of teaching throughout the Gospel.

verses.text: The Pharisee was astonished to see that He did not first wash before dinner.
verses.comment: Jewish traditions of ritual washing are highlighted. Jesus’ disregard signals priority of inward purity.

verses.text: And the Lord said to him, 'Now you Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and of the dish, but inside you are full of greed and wickedness.'
verses.comment: Jesus condemns superficial legalism and calls for true interior conversion, a core Gospel teaching.

verses.text: Foolish ones! Did not He who made the outside make the inside also?
verses.comment: Emphasizes God as Creator of both body and soul—the need for internal sanctity matches the external.

verses.text: But give as alms those things that are within, and see, everything is clean for you.
verses.comment: Alms giving is to flow from inner conversion—a spiritualized view of purification (see parallels in Matt. 6:1-4).

verses.text: 'But woe to you Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every herb, and neglect justice and the love of God. These you ought to have done, without neglecting the others.'
verses.comment: True law-keeping is not mechanical but demands heartfelt fidelity to justice and love.

verses.text: 'Woe to you Pharisees! For you love the best seat in the synagogues and greetings in the marketplaces.'
verses.comment: Warning against pride and seeking human honor; sanctity requires humility.

verses.text: 'Woe to you! For you are like unmarked graves, and people walk over them without knowing it.'
verses.comment: Unmarked graves transmit ritual impurity—Jesus accuses them of spreading spiritual death unaware.

verses.text: One of the law experts answered Him, 'Teacher, in saying these things You insult us also.'
verses.comment: Recognition that Jesus’ words extend to the teachers of the law, not the Pharisees alone.

verses.text: And He said, 'Woe to you also, law experts! For you load people with burdens hard to bear, and you yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers.'
verses.comment: The teachers create heavy moral codes but do not help carry them—contrasting with Christ’s call to mercy and mutual assistance.

verses.text: 'Woe to you! For you build the tombs of the prophets whom your fathers killed.'
verses.comment: They honor prophets after death but reject their message in life—highlighting the pattern of resisting God’s messengers.

verses.text: So you are witnesses, and you consent to the deeds of your fathers; for they killed them, and you build their tombs.
verses.comment: They continue ancestral rejection of the prophets, while maintaining an outward appearance of piety.

verses.text: Therefore also the Wisdom of God said, 'I will send them prophets and apostles, some of whom they will kill and persecute,'
verses.comment: 'Wisdom of God' is a personification, possibly referring to Christ Himself. Jesus claims divine prerogative to send prophets and apostles.

verses.text: so that the blood of all the prophets, shed since the foundation of the world, may be charged against this generation,
verses.comment: Christ reveals a coming judgment—those who reject the message of salvation face God’s justice.

verses.text: from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zechariah, who perished between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, I tell you, it will be required of this generation.
verses.comment: The entire Old Testament martyrdom history is encompassed here; Jesus claims authority over all redemptive history.

verses.text: 'Woe to you law experts! For you have taken away the key of knowledge. You did not enter yourselves, and you hindered those who were entering.'
verses.comment: By distorting or withholding understanding, they prevent others from finding the path to salvation. Christ calls for authentic teaching and guidance.

verses.text: As He went away from there, the scribes and the Pharisees began to press Him hard and to provoke Him to speak about many things,
verses.comment: His authoritative rebukes provoke hostility from religious leaders, escalating the conflict leading to Christ’s Passion.

verses.text: lying in wait for Him, to catch Him in something He might say.
verses.comment: Foreshadows the opposition and conspiracy that will culminate in the crucifixion, fulfilling the Scriptures (see Ps. 2:1-2).
